is a small city in the

. Iguape is a town from the colonial period that combines beautiful natural surroundings with a charming historic center, a national heritage site. If you do not have plans to visit the most famous Brazilian Colonial cities (such as
), then Iguape is certainly worth a visit.
It is speculated that the Spanish settlement in Iguape may have started in 1498,

Brazil was (at least officially) "discovered" by the Portuguese (in 1500). Iguape was officially founded in 1538 after a bloody fight between the Portuguese government and rogue aristocrats.

Iguape remained a quiet place for a long time, until the 19th century, when rice farming brought an economic boom to the city. Many historical constructions in the city are originals from this period. However, with the failure of an attempt to construct a canal for ships in the city, Iguape met economic decline in the early 20th century. For this reason, Iguape is nowadays a small city with an economy based on fishing and tourism.
. Reserving in advance is highly recommended.
Iguape has a single access through Rod. Prefeito Casimiro Teixeira (
). The road can be accessed from Rod. Régis Bittencourt (
. There is no direct connection between Iguape and the neighboring coastal city
The city's Historic Center can be easily explored on foot. A car will be handy to reach the Juréia beach and explore the Juréia-Itatins Ecological Station.
Iguape's city center contains several constructions from the 17th-19th centuries. The city contains the largest colonial heritage of
. As a relatively poor city, Iguape relies on state and federal help to maintain its heritage.

name=Basílica do Senhor Bom Jesus de Iguape
content=The city's main church, a Colonial-style church inaugurated in 1856, took 69 years to be built due the city's many economical struggles. The churches has paintings by Ernesto Thomazini.
content=One of Brazil's three oldest foundries, likely founded in the 1650s and used to make gold coins. Currently it is a museum dedicated to the history of the city.
alt=Igreja de Nossa Senhora do Rosário dos Homens Pretos
content=Colonial church built in the XVII century as a place of prayer for African slaves. Now it is a holy art museum with about 150 pieces.

content="Rua do Funil" is a nickname for the Rua das Neves, which has the shape of a funnel when seen of above. It is one of the most picturesque spots of the city, with a large collection of Colonial buildings.
directions=1.5 km east of the city center
content=A park in an elevated area, that provides an excellent panoramic view of the city and the surrounding nature, containing also a statue of Christ the Redeemer.
directions=18 km east of the city center
content=Surrounded by Atlantic rainforest, the long and unspoiled Juréia beach can be accessed by taking a ferry boat.
- The island just next to Iguape boasts an enormous beach, well-preserved nature and an area with sand dunes
- Previously called "Jacupiranga State Park", it contains a large original Atlantic rainforest reserve, the famous "Caverna do Diabo" (Devil's Cave) and the beautiful Lagamar de Cananéia
- One of the largest original Atlantic rainforest reserves of the country, hence with large animal biodiversity, also with the highest concentration of caves in the World
- A nice historic center and access to the unspoiled Cardoso island
